title: 110_hr6992
content: The Act titled "Reclamation Title Transfer Act of 2008" includes definitions for key terms. The Act "Reclamation Title Transfer Act of 2008" defines key terms such as "eligible facility" and "qualifying entity" for potential transfer of reclamation projects or facilities to agencies of State or local government, Indian tribes, or other entities with water service contracts. The Reclamation Title Transfer Act of 2008 defines key terms for transferring eligible facilities out of Federal ownership, with the Secretary of the Interior overseeing the process. The term "conveyed property" refers to facilities transferred under this Act. The Reclamation Title Transfer Act of 2008 defines key terms for transferring eligible facilities out of Federal ownership, with the Secretary of the Interior overseeing the process. SEC. 3 authorizes the Title Transfer Program. The Secretary will establish a Title Transfer Program to analyze and facilitate the transfer of eligible facilities out of Federal ownership for more efficient water management. The Secretary is authorized to convey all rights in eligible facilities to qualifying entities without further Congressional approval, while retaining mineral interests. The Secretary will retain mineral interests associated with conveyed property, manage them in accordance with Federal law, and convey water and facility interests through written Agreements with qualifying entities. The transfer of eligible facilities out of Federal ownership for efficient water management is facilitated through the Title Transfer Program. Before conveying land and facilities under this Act, the Secretary must comply with environmental and historic preservation laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act, the Endangered Species Act, and the National Historic Preservation Act. Eligibility criteria for title transfer under this Act are also outlined. The Secretary will establish criteria for title transfer eligibility under the Act within one year of enactment. Criteria include a qualifying entity accepting title, no significant environmental impact, consistent use of the property, protection of land and water resources for Indian tribes, and alignment with the Secretary's responsibilities. The transfer of assets must comply with international treaties and compacts. The qualifying entity must compensate the United States for the value of any repayment obligation or income stream derived from the assets. Water interests can only be conveyed with associated land or infrastructure and when the entity has a contractual right to the water. No conveyance under this Act may adversely impact power rates or repayment obligations, or include a Federal facility that produces power sold to power customers. SEC. 6. LIABILITY. The United States will not be liable for damages related to prior ownership or operation of conveyed property. SEC. 7. BENEFITS. Conveyed property is not part of a Federal reclamation project, and the new owner cannot receive project benefits except those available to others. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS. The entity receiving conveyed property must comply with all applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations. Ownership and pricing limitations of Federal reclamation law do not apply to water conveyed under this Act, except for project water from Federal reclamation facilities. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds may be appropriated for investigations and title transfer costs under this Act, including compliance with environmental laws. Expenditures by the Secretary are nonreimbursable. SEC. 10. REPORT. SEC. 10. REPORT. The Secretary must submit a report to relevant committees within two years of funds availability, detailing actions taken, conveyances made, federal funds used, and factors limiting conveyances. SEC. 11. RECLAMATION LAW. This Act amends and supplements the Act of June 17, 1902.
